{"step_by_step_thinking": "Porosity in dental porcelain can be caused by trapped air or gas bubbles in the material. These bubbles can expand during the baking process, creating pores. Therefore, to prevent porosity, it would be ideal to bake the porcelain in an environment where there is no air or gas that could be trapped in the material. This can be achieved by baking in a vacuum.", "answer_choice": "B"}
